results.content: I really enjoyed the well detailed examples that I can refer back to in the future.  I put all of these examples typed out with my own notes in comments in an accessible folder.  Even with the accent, he spoke clearly and at a good pace for me to understand.  Thanks for making this course.  It clarified content that my bootcamp passed over in 5 minutes.  I needed the full explanations.  Keep making lessons and I will keep trying more when I have a day available.

Viktor

results.content: The instructor is very knowledgeable.  There is a lot of good information in the course if you can get past some confusing examples.  I am not sure this course is for a beginner.
results.content_html: The instructor is very knowledgeable. There is a lot of good information in the course if you can get past some confusing examples. I am not sure this course is for a beginner.

results.content: I enjoyed this course. Viktor broke down everything in an easy to understand way. His accent is a bit thick, but I didn't think it hindered learning. I especially liked the video on the event loop, message queue, and call stack. I felt like it really demystified that process in a simple and clear way. I was able to take what I learned from this course and directly apply it to a project, which is exactly the result I wanted. Thank you for this concise course!

I especially liked the video on the event loop, message queue, and call stack. I felt like it really demystified that process in a simple and clear way. I was able to take what I learned from this course and directly apply it to a project, which is exactly the result I wanted. Thank you for this concise course!

First the good: I really enjoyed learning one of my favorite concepts in a more systematic way. I definitely walk away from this course with greater comprehension of async functions.

I am not sure if the instructor recorded the callbacks portion of the course at a different time from the Promises portion of the course. The former was little hard to understand and the latter was much better. I am not sure if it had to with accent/pace of speaking. I would say a re-recording of that portion would be better.

results.content:
Very good teaching, speaking very clearly and just the right pace.
One suggestion though: In the example basically validation of a parameter provided to function A was made in an async function B that function A calls.
This is not expected - I expect parameter validation for function A in this example to be the first line of code in the same function imo.
This fact steals some attention, I mean I'm thinking "why is he making parameter validation in the wrong place?". 
This possible initial confusion can be avoided if you use some other error scenario.
results.content_html:

results.content:
An excellent course that gave me a good beginning foundation on promises. I’ve taken numerous courses on Udemy these past several months. While some are better than others, it’s actually a bit of a stretch to call them courses. In reality, many of them are something like enhanced tutorials. There are lessons, and there is Q&A. However, they don’t necessarily qualify as legitimate courses in my opinion. Viktor’s course on promises does qualify as a fully legitimate course from a professional instructor, in my opinion.

A proper course includes an instructor or professor who is able to perform in the role at the professional level without question, or at least in most ways. The instructor is thereby able to articulate effective explanations of code and programming concepts with precision. An instructor is also able to field complex questions, and respond either by pointing the student in the direction of documentation that perfectly answers the student’s question or by answering the students question directly with thoroughness and clarity.

Many of the courses on Udemy are presented by guys who you wouldn’t necessarily think of as instructors or professors in the sense that you would for a university class. They are often really just guys who happen to know how to use a particular tool or set of tools and also happened to be lucky enough to have worked in software. But they don’t necessarily exhibit the knowledge and experience that you would often see in professors in the offline world. And for this reason, they will often answer questions with links to resources that don’t necessarily answer the student’s question very well or will simply not have the ability to articulate with thoroughness and clarity an  answer that you would expect from something like a university professor.

Victor’s pedagogy is at the professional level in the ways that I’ve described. Additionally, he appears to not only have laid out an outline for what he wants to present, but rather has also created a tight script along with predefined coding examples he plans to present. His course is thereby highly refined and polished.

I’m a guy in my 40s with two masters degrees and a career not in software that’s going nowhere. A year and a half ago, I decided I was going to study programming for as long as it took to get into the field that appears to me to be the absolute best bet for professional recognition, enjoyable building and engineering of creative works, and financial reward. Since January 2019 I have taken many courses on Udemy and otherwise, studying 6 or 7 days a week with a focus on getting my start as a QA tester after a friend clued me in on how high the demand is for this role.

I have increasingly begun to encounter the concept of promises in my study of QA testing and wanted to step away for some isolated study of this topic before returning to my progression of QA testing courses. So, I searched and found Viktor’s course, which is one of the best I’ve taken so far.
results.content_html:

A year and a half ago, I decided I was going to study programming for as long as it took to get into the field that appears to me to be the absolute best bet for professional recognition, enjoyable building and engineering of creative works, and financial reward. Since January 2019 I have taken many courses on Udemy and otherwise, studying 6 or 7 days a week with a focus on getting my start as a QA tester after a friend clued me in on how high the demand is for this role.

I have increasingly begun to encounter the concept of promises in my study of QA testing and wanted to step away for some isolated study of this topic before returning to my progression of QA testing courses. So, I searched and found Viktor’s course, which is one of the best I’ve taken so far.

results.content: This was an excellent course.  Similar to his course on Webpack, Viktor shows himself to be deeply knowledgeable and passionate about his subject matter.  He is also very intelligent in how and what he chooses to teach.  He focuses his teaching on presenting core concepts and not getting too far into the weeds of his subject matter so that one comes away with a strong overall understanding of the material.  Also, and most notably, his discourses feature extraordinary verbal clarity.  He also offers a wealth of additional information in the Q&A in his answers to thoughtful questions.  It is obvious from the meticulous presentations that he loves what he is doing and takes pride in their creation.  It was really a pleasure!

results.content:
I've been struggling a bit to learn callbacks and Promises in JavaScript and feel like this course did a great job of explaining the concepts and giving good examples for everything that was discussed. I also liked that the instructor took the time to re-explain concepts as they were revisited or built-upon throughout the course, which helped to really solidify the knowledge as I progressed. The material on testing asynchronous JavaScript code with Mocha and Chai was also a really nice bonus and happened to be something else that I needed to learn for work. Thanks, Viktor!

Notes:

To get the most out of this course, I would suggest on reading-up on callbacks and Promises a bit first to get a high-level idea of what they're about as a primer and I would also recommend learning a little about arrow syntax so it doesn't trip you up in the examples (you don't need to know much about it, just get somewhat visually familiar with it.)

One other thing to keep in mind is that the instructor uses Node throughout the course-- You DO NOT need to know any Node to understand the course material, but you will see a tiny bit of syntax that is associated with it (just something to be aware of.)

The material on testing asynchronous JavaScript code with Mocha and Chai was also a really nice bonus and happened to be something else that I needed to learn for work. Thanks, Viktor!
